title: MWE experiment: outline and results

author: Jaka Čibej, Center za jezikovne vire in tehnologije (CJVT), Univerza v Ljubljani

segmentation: As part of the work we're doing in Workgroup one.
And I'll just.
I'll try to be brief.
I actually concentrated this presentation from the material I had from Gothenburg.
And we had a whole hour to explain it to the participants.
There we only have 15 or 20 minutes here, so if there's anything that's unclear, you can talk to me later or to one of the other people involved.
We're all here.
So basically what we did was conducted crowdsourcing experiments to rank English multi word expressions according to their difficulty.
So L2 levels of proficiency basically.
Here we have some examples.
For instance to burn the midnight oil to be absorbed in something and so on.
We did this because we, well, we think that manual annotation with CFR levels is time consuming and difficult even for experts.
So we had this idea that maybe there's a better way in a similar way to do it.
And why not use crowdsourcing?
And so we said, let's try and see if this is possible.
This began last year when Elena had her SDSM and Juliana and we made a very brief.
Outline of the experiment.
Then I went to Gothenburg and we set up the experiment together with David.
And then the preparations for the workshop in December took place when we conducted the experiment and presented the results in December at the workshop.
I think most of the people who were at the workshop are also here today.
So I'm presenting this to the to the rest.
What we did was.
Well, we took English vocabulary profile, which is a.
To put it brief, a data set which, among other things includes multi word expressions in English ranked by CFR levels.
So from expressions in a 12 expressions in C2 and we decided to use this experiment to rank 60 expressions.
Multi word expressions, verbal ones and adverbial ones like to burn the midnight oil.
As I said before and happy New Year or by all accounts in the second group.
So.
What methods should we use to rank them?
So if you want to rank them on a scale from most difficult to easiest?
You can't really just take a list and divide the list among among multiple participants.
You can just say you rank the first 10 and you Rang the 2nd 10 because it doesn't really make sense.
You have to rank the entire list.

And ranking a subset of tasks is difficult because it's the combinations that you give to people might affect the results, and it's not very user friendly and it's very difficult to merge and to know which combinations to really use so.
We came up with the idea of using best worst scaling, which is a ranking method.
Where you simply choose the best and the worst unit in a combination of three to four candidates.
Ideally so, for instance, we have an example here if you have.
Four elements JKLM and you choose the best and the worst candidate.
You get.
Basically a combination saying that K is the best and L is the worst and the other two are in between.
So what information does that provide?
There are six possible binary relations between the four elements, so J&KJ&L and so on.
And if you use best worst scaling with four elements.

What you get from this ranking is 5 out of the six relations, which is basically 83% of the information that you can get, and you only use two clicks to get it by ranking all four elements, you would grant it get 6 out of 6 relations, so 100%, but you would need at least four clicks.
To get it and you have to consider all the elements.
So not just two which is twice the workload.
So we decided we should use this method and see if it works.
So we generated tasks for each project, adverbial and verbal multi word expressions.
Anne.

As you can imagine, I mean if you have 60 expressions that comes to about half a million combinations for combinations of four units, so you're not going to ask, you're not going to ask crowd sources to annotate half a million combinations.
So we used a certain algorithm to determine the minimum amount of tasks.
To cover all the binary relations among the elements and that was 326 tasks per project.
And we also made sure those tasks were non repetitive, so you don't have to click the same task or the same task.
The task contain the same relations more than once or twice, so most of them are non repetitive.
So our predictions were because we were planning on inviting about 20 people to participate in the experiment.

And with an average response time of 30 seconds, and if we wanted to collect 5 responses per task, then each crowdsourcing we had would have to solve 82 tasks for projects which would amount to about 40 minutes of their time.
And we said that was still manageable.
We then developed an interface in an open source crowdsourcing platform.
Pipasa.
I think most of you are familiar with it.
We also had a training school on it last year in Iasi.
So it was a very simple tasks the the crowdsourcing was just asked to choose the easiest and hardest expression out of the four and also had the opportunity to.
Ability to click on one of the expressions if they didn't know what it meant and they got the definition.
An example of use.
An app.
Do that, Oh yeah, we also provided them with some guidelines, but not much.
Is basically dead.
So they have to decide which expression is the most difficult or the easiest for a language learner to produce, not to understand, but to produce.
We made we made it very clear that we were looking for difficulty in terms of production, not reception.
If there was a tie, we were told they were told to just choose one at random and not to overthink the decision.
And as a general rule of thumb, try not to spend more than 30 seconds per task.

I would like to point out at this stage that there was no mention of the English vocabulary profile or CFR levels, so all the crowd sources for light only on their intuition on what was best and worst, so hardest and easiest.

And like I said, there were in the end there were 26 participants, mostly linguists and NLP experts, and 24 of them were non native speakers of English, while only two of them were native speakers and we separated those in a separate project.
So as not to contaminate the data.
Sorry for the expression.
So in the end.
And we got the annotations and we merge them in two ways.
And the first method was just using.

A very brute force approach to create a linear scale so to rank expressions from the most difficult to the easiest and we just took all the annotations for a specific expression, regardless of what expression it appears within a certain combination and just average the sum of the ranks, the expression God, so the difficult ones were assigned a rank of three, and the easier ones were assigned the rank of one while the other two were assigned a rank of two.
The premise is simple here.
I mean, harder expressions should more frequently be annotated as more difficult as rank three, and vice versa for the easier ones.
And we got this.
So this is the linear scale on the left side.
There's a zoom out of the entire scale and I color coded the expressions by color.
So from green, which is a 2 red which is C. And you can see that.

It's actually very surprising that despite the fact that most of the people were absolutely oblivious of the fact that we were using the English vocabulary profile and that we were actually trying to evaluate CFR levels.
This is the end result.
So I mean, I'm sure that most of the people who participated in the experiment experiments are very intelligent and had some sense of that.
We had a nefarious plot scheming in the background, but they still relied on their intuition on what they thought was.
The most difficult expression the easiest expression.
I think the results are actually quite useful and quite impressive.
To be honest.
I for instance were was pleasantly surprised because.
In general, when you do crowdsourcing, providing vague guidelines, and relying on subjective annotations is a big no no.
So this is a very pleasant result here.

A couple of closeups, so for C2 and C1, and for a two and a one, and you can see you get the higher levels you get expressions that are more semantically less transparent, like burn the midnight oil or grasp the nettle.
Throw in the towel and so on.
In the bottom you get expressions which you learn at a very early stage of language acquisition, like see you later.
I live in or live at.
Excuse me and so forth.
Then we had a second method of merging the results.
And we basically created a 60 by 60 matrix of all the average distances between the expressions so.
We created a series of embeddings.
For each expression containing the distances to all the other expressions.
And clustered them and used multidimensional scaling to visualize.
The data into in a more.
Um?
Visualizable space.
So these are the results of the clustering.
Uh.
So with with we used K means clustering with.
So six clusters an achieved an accuracy of 41% for adverbs and verbs, 50% for verbs, which is kind of low to be honest, but.
If you look at the confusion matrix.
At the bottom of the slide, this is for the verbal multi word expressions.

You can see that most Miss Misclassifications were between neighboring levels, so you have a lot of a ones that were assigned as a twos and C ones that were assigned to see twos, but there is no A1 that was assigned as a as a C2, or vice versa.
So it's still manageable.
And it also.
There's also this question whether the English vocabulary profile really is 100% reliable.
Now we also visualized the.
The data using the Tensorflow embedding projector.
We got this projection of a high dimensional space.
3D and you can see that here you also get interesting clusters from a one which is blue to a two, which is.
I'm not sure if you can see this.
Can you see this?
To a two which is yellow, then you have some great points which is B1B2 is lavender and might be kind of unclear.
On the projection.
There's the one which is red and see two, which is pink.
So there's this really nice progression.
And it's surprising because like I said, none of the crowd sources really knew what they were doing.
They were just relying on their intuition.
Still got a very similar results to what the English vocabulary profile.
Has done.
So to conclude, I would just like to point out that this experiment was meant to confirm that crowdsourcing can indeed be used to generate language learning resources.
Doing the literature overview which Illinois mentioned earlier today, we didn't really find any sort of work that dealt specifically with crowdsourcing for generating language learning exercises.
You have dual lingo, you have games with a purpose.
That collect data using a certain mechanism.
But not the other way around, so you don't really have crowd sourcing to generate language learning resources, so that's what we wanted to prove with this experiment.
That is indeed possible.
It doesn't really take that much effort, so the crowd sources didn't really need that much training.
Guidelines were just four bullet points long and the results were comparable to expert annotations, so it was a very impressive result.
There is still a lot of things to do though.

In future work we would like to see whether there is a difference between native and non native crowd sources because for this experiment we only used non native crowd sourcers and linguists basically.
So what about language learners?
Can they also solve a similar task and provide similar results?
And is there a difference with other languages because for instance you get a lot of L2 learners of English but not enough.
L2 learners for Spanish or.
I don't know, maybe Swedish and other languages, so we would like to try this out.
On other languages, to see whether it's doable, whether it provides similar results.
And that's it.
Thank you very much.
Thank you very much.
Yeah, go ahead.
I'm taking OK and I'll start walking there then any can you just give some details about times?
Just a bit about how you created the embedding.
I guess it was with surrounding contexts and how this does that make.
Then correlate with.
The levels yeah, this around the context also.
I mean basically the maybe I should have shown what the annotations looked like in the back end.
So you get a group of four expressions.
And the crowd sourcing chooses the easiest and the hardest one.
They all get numerical values assigned, so the easiest one is assigned the value of 1.
And the hardest one is assigned a value of three and the other two have the value of two.
And then you can calculate the distances between all of them.
So between one and two, there's a distance of two between two and three.
There's a distance of 1, so you always get an average.
Distance between those two expressions.
And then you get this matrix.
Where each expression.
Has the average distance to all the other expressions.
So thank you for this great dog.
Can you go back to the slide you just show before?

I think actually I missed at one point, but so my impression first was that the expression were provided out of context, but I see you have actually one example, yeah, So what is the case for all expressions?
This is this is actually at.
First, this element is not present.
The meaning in the example element.
But if you click on one of the expressions you get.
The definition and example and do you know whether people use that or not?
Because my question was if you present Multiword expression out of context, would would not that not kind of bias towards.
Semantically, OPAC expression that maybe in a context would.
Become a bit more clear.
You do you see what I mean?
Yeah yeah.
Yeah, actually we we did see.
A similar thing where some of the B twos, for instance, were classified as C ones or very close to see ones.

It also had to do with the fact that some of the multi word expressions were polysemous, so they had multiple meanings, and I assume that the annotator just assumed one meaning and didn't really Click to see what the meaning was, so that might be a problem with this sort of interface.
But it's just a pilot experiment, so we did consider it though.
Thank you so you didn't try to have to check the result for semantically open pack and non semantically or pack expression and see if there is any difference, I mean.

We didn't really categorise them into semantically opaque and semantically transparent, because at first we just wanted to look at the CFR levels, but that's something that we should definitely look at.
Yeah, OK, thank you.
OK.
I have a very general question.
After listening, you're actually very interesting research.
What do you think about that this intuition based research is the future of research.
I mean that the research is done without any criteria, it just some based on intuition.
And it's kind of what do you think what your thoughts about it?
It's it's intuition based research.
I think it's useful in certain cases.
Because if it's something.
That most people should agree on.
Intuition based approaches are.
OK, I think, but if it's something that.
I mean for instance.
Yeah I I should mention that we also had a feedback questionnaire.
I think you can see the link here.
In the interface.
There's a link to the feedback questionnaire right at the bottom, so if someone wanted to comment on their decision, they could leave feedback.
So we also have that I didn't put it in the presentation, but we do have a couple of comments from the crowd.
Sourcers, you know what?
What was their general criterion for deciding what was difficult and what was easy?
So you don't, you don't just get the intuition, you also get the reasoning behind the intuition I guess.
So you use that to interpret something.
Hi, thank you for the presentation.
Just something remark and question.
The remark is that it's not really crowdsourcing innocence.
That is not an open call it in a closed world an it's not really non experts that you have.
You really had experts and that answers partially what beat us just told us because you had linguist.
So it's not exactly.
It doesn't mean it's not relevant, it's very useful.
That's not my point what I'm saying.
It's you beware when you say it's non expert.
First you have to define what you mean by that but.
My question is really.
People who participated were motivated increasingly because it was part of their interest to participate.
How would you motivate other people to participate to such a study?
Well, we did discuss that as well, although we didn't come that far as to have an entire plan on how to motivate the entire planet to annotate multi word expressions, but.
Um, I suppose I mean a lot of things can be done through gamification.
Or if you use this as a sort of exercise.
But we haven't really come that far so, but I do realize that yeah, this is not.
I mean, this experiment is not really the classical crowdsourcing that people usually talk about.
I mean, you can have crowdsourcing with different groups and.
Well, crowd sources can can.
You can get crowd sources with different requirements to participate in your experiment.
But this was just.
The first step, so to speak.
Thank you.
